Name: São Paulo
Namesake: The state and city of São Paulo[1]
Fate: Sank 1951 while en route to be scrapped
Draft:
24 ft 8.75 in (7.5375 m) normal[4]
27 ft 3 in (8.31 m) full load[4]
Propulsion:
2-shaft reciprocating vertical triple-expansion (VTE) steam engines[6]
18 Babcock & Wilcox boilers[6]
Endurance: 10,000 nautical miles @ 10 knots (11,500 mi @ 11.5 mph or 18,500 km @ 18.5 km/h)[2]
Armament:
12 × 12-inch (304.8 mm) main guns (6 × 2)[4]
22 × 4.7 in (120 mm) guns[6]
18 × 3-pounder (47 mm) guns
8 × 1 pdr (37 mm) guns
Armour:
Belt: 9 to 3 in (229 to 76 mm) (upper belt 9 in)[6]
Upper deck: 1.5 in (38 mm)[6]
Main deck: 2 in (51 mm)[6]
Turrets: 12 in (300 mm) face, 8 in (200 mm) sides, 3 to 2 in (76 to 51 mm) roofs[6]
Barbettes: 9 in (230 mm)[6]
Conning tower: 12 in (300 mm),2 in (51 mm) sides and roof[6]
Notes: Characteristics are as built; cf. Specifications of the Minas Geraes-class battleships
